post.body: yeah, so this is a thing now. ZeroNet. Literally the most exciting tech I've seen in years.

Thinking what to do with the space that I'm given here. Looks like Twitter. Sure. Is there a character limit? None that I can see. Still, would I want to blog here? Not really. Formatting is one thing I miss. So Twitter, then.
Wondering if anyone is interested in #photography on ZeroMe or the entire ZeroNet, even. Might even start a photography related blog over here.
3 inks in a printer, you're buying a set. 9 inks in the printer, you're buying ink all the time, just different colours. I should maybe stock up.
Aaaand it's one in the morning again, guess which lucky person will be super tired tomorrow morning. Yes. Me. Go me.
Bought a bunch of 5 metre (15 feet) cables and put my desktop pc in another corner. Why didn't I do this earlier?
and one of those 15 feet cables doesn't do what I need done. Meh. need a new HDMI cable that does 4k@60hz ycbcr 444.
bought Grim Dawn more than three years ago, in early access. I must say it became quite a fun game. Loving it so far.

Someone on ZeroTalk said that ZeroNet might be dead. I don't know. Is it dead? From the little I've seen of it, I'd argue that it's very much alive despite its comparatively small size. Bit of a wild west, sure. Bit quiet at times? Absolutely. Is it dead? Nah. I don't think so.

The thing that made the regular internet great was awesome content added to it by its users. If there are resources on a network to be discovered, the network gets used.

Lost hot water and heating today. Perfectly timed so as to stop me from going out for a pint with old workmates.

Went ahead and fixed the boiler to avoid freezing to death. This has got to be one of the most British problems. I can not honestly say that I hold British boiler engineering to the highest esteem.
Have been editing video all day. I really need to get quicker at this, my life feels like it's seeping away slowly.

It is now so cold in my shed, that I'm contemplating getting a GPU or two and mining something to make up for at least some of the electricity cost I'm incurring heating the place anyway. Wondering what to mine that's not a complete loss, and with what. Got a 1080ti and a 970 to start with.

comment.body: @Krixano: well, I had absolutely *no idea*. Thanks!

@Krixano: and as for ZeroMedium, also a good shout! I'll have a look at it later today when I have a bit more time. I just love that the majority of the functionalities are already covered on Zero. Awesome stuff. I'll have to think how I share bigger files, though. RAW photos and the like. Might not end up needing to share them, but you know. Just in case.

@Git Center: I'm getting all my techie friends to try it out, mostly because I just find the technology absolutely fascinating. It's the sort of pipe dream software engineers come up with after a beer or five in a pub, and then completely forget about in the morning. Except it's implemented and works. Not only that, but it is *slick*.

So for now I'm getting folks to have a look. Personally I'm thinking about starting a blog of sorts on Photography. The idea that there's no monetary incentive is enticing to me (yes I know, bitcoin donations, but the potential audience is just not big enough for it to be a sole or even a serious motivation).
@Buizel:I sure will, once I know what form the site/zite will take! For now I'm spitballing what to do with it.

@Vper: "oh, of course there's another take to look at."
... *dying slowly*

@Buizel: That's a very good idea, actually. If we could do it using some of the non-legacy image codecs, it'd be even better. Storage requirements need not be humongous either. The site could default to some web-friendly resolution on the stored images, like 800px wide. The author of the image would host this and the full-res upload, which could be an optional download next to it.
